We'd find out.

My Michael.
I still love you.
And I don't know if love is the heart of poetry.

I mean, the wonderful thing about if you
take on poetry as a vocation is that you

But I think that it's certainly not out of fear
that one writes poetry, which I think
is I'm haunted by this sort of definition I heard many,
many years ago by Emmett Fox, which
talks about if you're not feeling love, you're feeling fear.
And that basically we in one way or another
we're feeling one of those emotions all the time.
So I always think of poetry as the way

It's a place to let everything happen and not a place to.
It's not a place for self-censorship.
And I think any place that is not about self-censorship

I don't really want any to say a word or two about yourself.
Oh, I'm Michael Klein.
I'm a poet and a writer.

I've written three books of poems.
I wrote a book of essays called The End

is about my experience.
Grooming a Kentucky Derby Horse in 1984, who died.

So I write about it a lot of things.
And I have a certain book of poems that just came out
in January called The Talking Day.
I'm Andrea Beyer.
I'm the curator of Italian Renaissance paintings
at the Metropolitan Museum.
And I'm here because I was the curator of this exhibition,
art and love in Renaissance Italy.
And actually, I did think of an anecdote
that I wanted to begin this discussion with,
because the point of this exhibition
was to bring together as wide a variety of objects
and paintings that had been made during the Renaissance
that celebrated those great ritual moments in people's
lives, betrothal marriage, the beginning of a family.
And in fact, we wanted to call the exhibition something
about marriage, marriage in the family, et cetera.
And the powers that be at the Met made us do a survey.
And they found out that the word marriage was such a turn-off
that they would not allow us to proceed with that in our title.
And so they encouraged us instead to use the word love.
And my colleagues, some of whom were much more academic
than I am, were appalled by this because there
was so little love in Renaissance marriage arrangements
that they felt that we were, in some ways,
distorting the conversation.
However, I ended up seriously disagreeing
with that point of view, and I was very happy that love was
in the title.
And if I have another two minutes,
I'll just tell you a great Renaissance anecdote.
You can probably all bring to mind
the beautiful Titian Venus of Ourobino in the Uffizi.
That painting was done for the Duquito Baldo della
Rovare in 1538.
And he wrote a very famous letter to Titian
in which he says, don't sell that nude lady to anyone else.
And that's the way he describes it.
But to me, the thing that was so touching
and interesting about that story,
Guido Baldo della Rovare at that moment
is married in a dynastic marriage with someone
he had had no interest in, and in fact,
who was prepubescent when they got married.
But he had been in love, deeply in love, the year before.
He was forced to marry that lady.
And I just wanted to read to you his letter to his father
briefly, briefly.
For two years now, I've spoken at length,
begging you that in giving me a wife,
it would seem that in this act, the principal matter
is to satisfy me, given that I carried and still
carried such a love for the Lady Clédice.
This is Clédice Oceini, due to her qualities and her manners.
To let me have her would give me such extreme happiness
and not to have her would cause me such infinite sadness.
So I beg you with all my heart, if you have any regard
for my sanity and health, satisfy and concede me this favor,
knowing that in her is my all.
Well, her father said no.
Her mother said no.
She was married the next year to an 11-year-old,
and then bought the Venus of Urbino
to put in his nuptial chamber.
So love is a complicated story in the Renaissance, too.
Under Andrea, it was modest in not telling us

Listen.

My name is Dan Slater.

I'm a writer.

So it was a lot to handle at one time,

And she said to me, well, some of my patients
fed luck with online dating.
So me should give that a shot.

And I started doing online dating,
and that began to become a focus of the sessions.
And she was asking me, well, what are the sites?
I'm almost like she was using the sessions

And to her patients, because she'd

And she said to me, she said, well, maybe one day

And as I was saying downstairs, I said,
there was no way I would write a book about this.
But after a few more things happened,
one of which was finding out that my mom and dad

I started to get serious as a researcher and a journalist
looking into the online dating business
and how it was affecting modern relationships.
So the product was out as a book that I published last month.
It's called Love and the Time of Algorithms.
It was excerpted in the Atlantic magazine this last month.
And so I've been out speaking about the book.

There's a lot of psychology in the book.
There's a lot of business reporting.
There's a lot of narrative.

That it's of matters.
That it matters a lot.

it's interesting, I think we've become

Like 20 years ago.
I mean, it was a very different way of courting.

how do we acclimate to using different phenomenology

it's very different than having an instinct for somebody

So I think one of the ways that online dating makes a difference

And one of the many results of that
is that you invent an idea in your head of what he or she

And then, of course, at some point,
you have to actually go meet them,

And for some people, that can be a lot of disappointment.
Because if the fantasy becomes very intense,
then you ultimately have to reconcile the person with the fantasy,
and that can be a disappointing process.
But I think that's part of a learning curve thing.
I think the people who do online dating for a while,
they learn hopefully to get past that.
I was saying to Lucy before we started

At least they're getting out there and meeting people

So I don't know if I've answered anything that you.
Nobody's interested in what they do.
But then again, what is the authentic self that

Who is this?
Well, forget the avatar.
The avatar is just a way of meeting.
OK.
The avatar, I mean, unless for you,
romance, love, and companionship means sitting in a room

that's not the case.
Ultimately, it's about meeting someone.
So the way I think of it is that in a way,

No, you're not spotting them across the room,

It's a fun thing to focus on because it can be funny.

that in fact it's best not to meet that ideal love.
And many of the poets never did meet that ideal love.

But it is, in a way, it's the same kind of thing

And then you came to romantic love,
which different people have different definitions of.
So I thought maybe.
So for my definition I like comes from Lane Hatfield
for romantic love, and it's the intense desire
for emotional union with another person.
Unity, did you say?
Emotional union.
Union.
With another person.
That intense desire for emotional union.
That is how romance can begin.
And certainly what I'm talking about,
you could use the word infatuation.
It can start out that way.
Where one of the things that we asked people
who we were interviewing to become subjects
in the experiment, the most important question,
was what percentage of the day do you think about this person?
Now most of the people who were part of this study

I can't stop thinking about them.
I can't sleep.
They're totally obsessed with the other person.
That doesn't last all that long, usually.
I mean, you can't not sleep.
People who are in love in the early stages often lose weight.
That's one of the symptoms too for being in love.
You have to moderate a little bit,
and a little bit of attachment sets in,
because you have to go to work and do other things

So this intensity, you can call infatuation, I guess.
But what's interesting to me, one of the interesting things

when they looked at a picture of their beloved,
their sweetheart, their romantic partner,
I thought maybe it would activate parts of the brain
that have to do mainly with cognition,
recognizing something attractive about the other person.
So remember, they've already fallen in love with the person.
What was fantastic was the area of the brain that was active
was deep in a reflex level part of the brain.
It's called the brainstem.
It's a reward system that neuroscientists had identified.
But at a very primitive level of the brain,
totally, dare I say, the unconscious level,

Anyway, a part of the brain that is not just human at all,
part of the brain we share with other mammals.
And it's this primitive system.
Our sense that water tastes good when we're thirsty.
It's like thirst.

as a matter of fact, poetry, I think,
uses the word thirsty when I hunger after my beloved.
I'm thirsty for you.
That is a poetry and literature often describes very well
what kind of findings that we saw in the brain as we look back.

of the reward system that mediates basic drives
like hunger and thirst.
But right next to that area, actually,
is another area that we found was activated
just by the attractiveness of the face.
So you can maybe sit down at a coffee shop
with someone, see them the first time,
and you have a reaction to them.
And you know the face is attractive.
In a general sense, there's a beauty that we all see in art.
You know, there's a.
And psychologists call this the difference
wanting and liking so you can want someone.
And that can be, goodness knows,
that the face has to be somewhat attractive to you,
but there are other things.
And maybe it does have to do with your experiences

And there's something about that person that reminds you of them.
But you focus on that person.
You want that person versus liking them to start with.
And liking can turn into wanting, actually.
But that the brain studies identified very nicely

I'd be very interested to know how much of that liking side
is inherent to one person or is really
conditioned by cultural norms.
So that, again, to come back to the kind of descriptions

So you can imagine that, first of all, people

Are they responding to something that's

Is that a cue for me to say something?
One of the things I found when I
interviewed over 100 online daters for this.
And one of the things that I would hear over and over again

the ideal and sort of inventing the ideal early on.
And then having to kind of reconcile the reality

when you're feeling a tense romantic love,
one at least in my own experiences and the experiences

And part of that intensity was sort of inventing an ideal,
oh my god, this person's amazing.

And she's funny and all this.

You know, whatever your thing is, whatever your little,

The ideal is kind of shattered.
And I think that with online dating,
one of the things online dating allows you to do

because just because you can meet more people.
It's got to, you know, I want to feel that again.
I want to feel that infatuation.
So I met a lot of people who would kind of, you know,
the serial online data that the person who always

I also think that if it's real love,
there has to be a spiritual element to it.

But he said this great thing that love was being engaged

It could be physical or emotional or, I mean,
I think that covers a lot of ground, even sexually.
I think it could cover ground.
But sat the idea of getting something back in a relation,
in a love relationship, I think is where it gets screwy.
I really do.
I mean, and particularly when you have love
for something that is not a person.
I mean, I love many, many things in the world
that have nothing.

the conversation seemed to be moving in the direction

And I thought, well, I could let this go on

you don't have to apologize for bringing the unconscious

The aspect of falling in love and being in love
and relating in general has, to my way of seeing it,
always involves images that people have of the other.
And they either want to find that image out there somewhere,
or if they don't find it, they will try to create that image,
some image they have within themselves
of what they would feel most comfortable with.
And then they will try to induce the image of the other
in images that they have of that person.
Of course, it gets further complicated
by the other person that similarly has images.
And that's where my profession comes in,
because when I, there's a couple of therapists,
almost always the problem, presenting problem,
is the image that people have of one another
doesn't fit the person who they're with.
And that seems to me the human condition.
There's nobody who's going to be a symbiotic twin,
or be exactly the way you want them to be,
or to be the same as you.
And so I did want to bring that up as a...
So, first, how do you avoid that trap?
Which trap?
Well, I mean...
Looking for your twin.
Well, there are a number of ways to do that.
In the therapeutic world, there are two ways
that that can happen in the traditional psychoanalytic framework.
A patient comes in and begins to transfer feelings
onto the analysts that are totally sort of in their head.
And the analyst then tries to interpret what image
are they trying to create in the analyst
is it some version of a sibling,
or a parent, a father, or a mother.
And by gaining some insight into that,
they can say, well, this is something I have to keep my eye on,
that I don't fall into that trap
that you sort of suggest that we all fall into.
Now, when I see a couple, in some ways,
it's somewhat easier to me because each party
is projecting onto the other person
some irrational parts of themselves.
And one can do two for the press of one, so to speak.
The transparencies are going on both ways.
And so you can then begin to examine that
and help them also get greater insight
into who they are, what they're about, and who they want to be.
Before, when you were telling me about your analyst
said to you, there's a book in there.
I thought to myself, my analyst never told me
there was a book in the middle of me.
I didn't have an analyst who told me

But I wasn't told that I had a book that might come out.
Now, that's a different intervention
that your analyst got.
I was like, I'm a career coach.
Huh?
Yeah, I would.
So, but this goes on in the analytic and in the therapeutic
room as well, that is there are transparencies

and it keeps changing even between the same two people.
And it's a developmental process, what's more,
and it goes through a lot of stages that may begin with infatuation
or some kind of erotic chemical response, may begin with an awful lot of projection.
I think that's always there.
And then may head into romantic emotional union,
and people might live together, try to make an everyday life together through that.
And then there's a developmental stage that I think is as important as any other,
and I would call it disappointment, because there's a fall into disappointment
with a couple just as there is a falling into love.
And when you get to disappointment, that's a very, very important kind of choice point,
because how people treat their disappointment is going to tell everything
about whether they might grow together into a more mature kind of loving
or wind up partying into self-preservation
and a change from abundance into scarcity
and a sort of Darwinian struggle for control of the relationship
and whose needs get met.
And it goes from there.
So I think, and as Walter Benjamin once said,
the important thing is not love at first sight, it's love at last sight.
And that's that stage of growing old together and facing each other's mortality.
So it's a long developmental process, and I think we have to be very careful not to be reductionist
and say love is a this or that.
